articles.title: Alberta government pushing Hinton, other communities for more wildfire mitigation work
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: A helicopter works a forest fire outside of Jasper, Alta., on July 26, 2024.    Amber Bracken and The Canadian Press have a photo of the incident. It is taking place in the area of forest fire. The helicopter is working the fire.

articles.title: Greenland's glaciers are melting faster than anyone expected
articles.author: The Jerusalem Post
articles.summary: For the first time, we are able to see significant increases in the size and depth of crevasses at fast-flowing glaciers at the edges of the Greenland Ice Sheet, according to the scientists.       "For the  first time we can see significant rises in the number of glaciers.

articles.title: Another unwelcome consequence of climate change: an explosion of urban rats
articles.author: Karen Kaplan Los Angeles Times
articles.summary: The warmer it gets, the faster rats multiply in cities that already struggle to contain them, according to a new study. The study was published in the journal "Climatology" by the University of California, Los Angeles. It is based on climate change research.

articles.title: More rain on the way in flood-hit regional communities
articles.author: Savannah Meacham
articles.summary: Flood-weary northern Queensland residents are bracing for more rising floodwaters as yet another deluge is forecast to hit the drenched region. The current deluge has already deluged the area and is expected to continue for the next few days.

articles.title: Carolina Panthers donate $20,000 to Fletcher school devastated by Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Justin Berger
articles.summary: Carolina Panthers Charities will give $20,000 to Fernleaf Community Charter School in Fletcher, N.C., which suffered damages from Hurricane Helene. Two of FernLeaf's main athletic fields, athletic equipment, and athletic storage facilities were destroyed by the storm. The school has already taken measures to rebuild.

articles.title: Auckland Council Urges Vigilance Against Wildfire Risks In Regional And Local Parks
articles.author: New Zealand Government
articles.summary: Wildfires in California, bushfires in Australia and significant vegetation fires across Aotearoa are a reminder of the risks posed by wildfires in Auckland's regional and local parks. Climate change is intensifying conditions that could increase the likelihood of fires, particularly with the shift from last summer's El Niño to La Niña, bringing drier and windier summer months. Auckland Council is taking proactive steps like controlling highly flammable invasive exotic species like hakea where it can, but visitors must observe fire bans, stay cautious and be mindful of conditions, especially on windy days.

articles.title: The world is warming up faster than ever
articles.author: Gwynne Dyer
articles.summary: The Copernicus website shows that the average global temperature is now +1.75 degrees Celsius (°C). Two years ago, the Earth System took off and in one month the temperature was + 1.5°C higher. The leading "mainstream" climate scientists downplay the seriousness of what is happening. The Paris Agreement settled on a "never exceed" target of +2.0°C.

articles.title: Climatologist Alan Robock on why he doubts we can geoengineer
articles.summary: Alan Robock is one of the world's leading experts on the climatic effects of a nuclear conflict and on geoengineering. He's in New Zealand and giving a talk tonight at Victoria University of Wellington on the human toll of nuclear winter. The Bulletin of Atomic Scientists moved the Doomsday Clock forward by a second to make it 89 seconds to midnight.

articles.title: Arkansas is warming up and farmers are dealing with the consequences
articles.author: Ainsley Platt
articles.summary: Little Rock, Fayetteville, Fort Smith and Jonesboro are getting warmer, according to federal data compiled by Climate Central. Temperatures in Arkansas have been trending upwards since 1970.      .   "Climate Central is a policy-neutral nonprofit that researches climate change.

articles.title: Henry VIII castle could be cut off from mainland under rewilding plans
articles.author: Joe Pinkstone
articles.summary: Environment Agency is creating a strategy to protect a mile-long shingle stretch of the Hampshire coastline against the impacts of climate change. It involves realigning the landform and creating new embankments to allow the land to flood and transition into salt marsh over time. Critics say Hurst Spit, home to the artillery fort Hurst Castle, built in the 1540s, could become cut off from the mainland as a consequence of the plans.

articles.title: Rising Temperatures Could Make One-Third of the Planet Uninhabitable, Alarming New Study Says
articles.author: Ryan Whalen
articles.summary: A third of the planet could become inhospitable to vulnerable populations if temperatures rise more than 2°C above preindustrial levels. An area equivalent to the size of the U.S. could become too hot for many to maintain safe body temperatures. The portion of planet deemed unsafe for older adults would increase by 35% and the regions dangerous even for young people would triple.

articles.title: 2025 January hottest on record – we are in so much danger now
articles.author: Martyn Bradbury
articles.summary: Last month was the warmest January on record, with surface – air temperatures 1.75C above preindustrial levels. Sea-surface temperatures remained unusually high in many ocean basins and seas. Almost 600 000 workers couldn't go to work in California in January because of the climate change.

articles.title: Fresh dusting of snow for many in Lower Mainland Sunday morning
articles.author: Alex Browne Peace Arch News
articles.summary: Environment Canada issues an arctic outflow warning for Sea to Sky, Squamish and Whistler for Superbowl Sunday. The weather forecast is mainly clear, cold and sunny for the next week in Metro Vancouver and the Fraser Valley. Wind chill values near -20C overnight and into morning hours.

articles.title: SCP 2025: HEDA urges governors to harness climate predictions for economic prosperity
articles.author: Henry Uche
articles.summary: The Human and Environmental Development Agenda (HEDA Resource Centre) has called on Nigerian governors to harness climate predictions for economic prosperity. This appeal comes as NiMet unveils its 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) which provides valuable insights into expected weather patterns.

articles.title: How To Lose The Planet: The Truth Behind Climate Change Denialism
articles.author: Om Prakash Dwivedi
articles.summary: In 2019, more than 11,000 scientists signed a statement warning of the 'catastrophic threat' posed by climate change. The Global North enjoys rich resource and a much safer environmental ecosystem. Global South experience the same level of loss and violence. Global North recover much faster due to a robust economic system. Alternative für Deutschland (AfD) party is overtly sceptical and critical of the European Union.

articles.title: Senate backs climate-resilient PH
articles.author: Manila Standard
articles.summary: The climate crisis is no longer a distant threat for the Philippines. The Senate declares an environment and climate emergency for the protection and preservation of the environment. The declaration is necessary for the resiliency and adaptability to the effects of climate change and for livelihoods.

articles.title: I'm not saying we're all doomed but the heat is on
articles.summary: The Copernicus website shows that the average global temperature is now +1.75°C. This year will be worse than last year in terms of weather, and next year it will be even worse. The media and most of their customers are ignoring this terrifying trend because the Tangerine Toddler is having a tantrum. A global emergency measures are needed now.

articles.title: Supercomputer Predicts the Year Humanity Will Go Extinct—the Timeline Is Set
articles.author: Arezki Amiri
articles.summary: In 250 million years, Earth's landmasses will merge, forming a new supercontinent dubbed Pangaea Ultima. This new landmass will be superheated and hot, turning vast regions into deserts unfit for mammals. 92% of the planet's landmass could become uninhabitable for mammals, leaving only polar and coastal regions as potential refuges.

articles.title: Scientists have some novel ideas to save the ice caps. Here are the most out-of-the-box suggestions
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: Glaciers are melting and sea levels are rising due to human-caused climate change. Two-thirds of glaciers are expected to disappear by 2100, according to a study published in the journal Science. Scientists are developing mitigation and adaptation strategies that they think could help us and the glaciers from worsening impacts.

articles.title: Extreme Arctic Warming Pushes North Pole Temperatures Above Freezing
articles.author: Bhupendra Singh Chundawat
articles.summary: Temperatures at the North Pole have surged above freezing. It's one of the most dramatic and alarming climate events in the history of the Arctic region. It is faster than the global average warming and it's affecting the polar bears. It also affects the Arctic indigenous communities.

articles.author: Guest Blogger

The developed countries' emissions are lower than in 1988 due to the development of renewable energy.

articles.title: How To Lose The Planet: The Truth Behind Climate Change Denialism
articles.author: News18

articles.title: Pakistan Can't Afford ‘Business as Usual': Why Climate Action is Key to Growth
articles.summary: Pakistan contributes less than 1% to global emissions, but it faces some of the most devastating consequences of climate change. articles.title: The average global temperature anomaly is now +1.75°C
articles.author: Gwynne Dyer
articles.summary: The average global temperature is now +1.75°C. Two years ago it was -1.2°C, but it went up to +.1.5°C in June 2023, and it has never dropped back down again. This year will be far worse than last year in terms of wild weather. The climate change is caused by greenhouse gases emitted by human civilisation.

articles.title: January 2025 hottest on record despite US cold and La Niña
articles.author: Patrick Pester
articles.summary: Last month was the hottest January on record, according to climate scientists. Global surface air temperatures averaged 55.81 degrees Fahrenheit (13.23 degrees Celsius) in January 2025, up from 55.65 degrees Fahrenheit in 2024. The current La Niña arrived later than scientists expected and is unusually weak.

articles.title: Kenora Weather: Bitter Cold with a Chance of Flurries – Bundle Up!
articles.author: Net News Ledger Weather Desk
articles.summary: Kenora and Lake of the Woods region are waking up to a bone-chilling morning this Sunday, February 9, 2025. The current temperature at Kenora Airport is -23.9°C, but with a south-southwest wind at 11 km/h, the wind chill makes it feel like a brutal -32°C. There is a 40% chance of flurries this afternoon, and the high will be -13°C with a wind chill of -31°C this morning. It will be even colder on Monday, with a mix of sun and cloud and a high of -20°C and a low of -24°C overnight.

articles.title: After the cold weather in Laos, heatwaves expected to threaten agriculture and public health
articles.summary: In April, temperatures in Laos exceeded 40 degrees celsius, prompting the government to temporarily halt classes in schools without air conditioning or fans. In the Philippines, more than thousands of schools were closed due to the peak of heat. The extreme heat also damaged rice crops and caused eggs to shrink in Thailand.

articles.title: How to avoid anarchy in Antarctica
articles.author: Economist
articles.summary: There is a growing scramble for the Antarctic. Seven countries have territorial claims over the land mass. Russia opened its tenth base this year and China its fifth. India is building a third and Turkey is planning its first. Iran has not signed the treaty but wants an Antarctic base to claim its 'property rights'.

articles.title: Climate extremes threaten everything from Florida crop yields to grocery prices
articles.author: Naples Daily News

articles.title: See sparrowhawks, kestrels, buzzards, red kites and falcons

articles.summary: Sparrowhawk is the bird of prey you're most likely to see in your garden. Kestrels are a similar length to a sparrowhawk but with longer wings and they glide less frequently. Buzzards are a medium-sized, stocky raptor with a compact body, short neck and small, black-tipped yellow plumage. Golden eagles are less compact, with longer, white and white-tailed eagles.

articles.title: 'Global weirding': How our 'normal' is becoming more extreme
articles.author: Charis Chang
articles.summary: There is a decline in frosty days in Melbourne. The Trump administration is moving to cut diversity, equity, and inclusion programs at the National Institutes of Health and National Science Foundation. Elijah urges readers to contact their representatives to oppose RFK Jr. for Secretary of HHS.

The U.S. has the largest carbon footprint in the world because of its significant energy consumption that is largely fossil fuel-based. articles.title: Korea faces intensifying heat waves due to climate change
articles.author: Kim Hyun-bin
articles.summary: The first day of a heat wave now arrives earlier in the year, while the last day occurs later, signaling a lengthening and intensification of these extreme heat events. Last summer's total of 22 tropical nights in Korea set an all-time high.

articles.title: Saving Australia's priority species from extinction would cost 10 billion U.S. dollars annually
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Saving Australia's priority species from extinction would cost almost 10 billion U.S. dollars annually for 30 years, according to a report published on Tuesday. The report found that preventing extinction for 99 priority species would cost 10 billion dollars per year. Turning this tragedy around will take a dramatic increase in action and investment.

articles.title: By 2100, heat waves in Korea could begin as early as May
articles.author: Lee Jung-joo
articles.summary: In 1994, Korea saw 28.5 heat wave days between June and August, which was surpassed in 2018 with 31 days. Last year, South Korea experienced 24 heatwave days, the third-highest number on record. In 1994 and 2018, Korea also experienced a significant number of tropical nights with 16.5 nights. In 2024, tropical nights lasted into September in Korea for the first time since 1973. The KMA predicted that heat waves will intensify in the Korean peninsula if greenhouse gas emissions are not reduced.

articles.title: Hawaii: The Rainbow Capital's Colorful Tapestry
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Hawaii's abundant sunshine, occasional rain showers, and pristine air make it the perfect environment for dazzling rainbows. articles.title: Targeting The Net Zero Equation
articles.author: Nazish Sheikha
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures are causing more frequent extreme weather events and environmental disasters. articles.title: Green Guardians: How Trees Combat Urban Heatwaves
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: There is an urban heat island effect where temperatures are higher in cities than in rural areas. Trees can reduce these elevated temperatures through shading and a process called transpiration. Evapotranspiration can lower temperatures by up to 4°C. Tree numbers are declining in many Australian cities due to housing developments that overlook their importance.

articles.summary: Caribbean region is at a potential inflection point. It is vulnerable to extreme weather events, crime, low productivity and growth, and food security. One Caribbean aims to enhance climate resilience, increase growth and promote social development across the region.

articles.title: Common Starling entertaining Isle of Wight gardeners
articles.author: IW Natural History
articles.summary: Starlings are widespread in the countryside on farmland, woodland, wetlands and coasts all through the year. There are greater numbers between November and February when they migrate from Scandinavia southwards for the winter. Starlings are a little smaller than a blackbird and have a short tail, pointed beak and triangular wings. They make a loose bulky nest of grass and stems lined with moss, roots, sheep's wool and feathers in tree holes or cavities in buildings, roof spaces or walls.

articles.title: Australian PM urges action on Indigenous welfare

articles.summary: Indigenous people in Australia have shorter lifespans, poorer health and higher incarceration rates than their non-Indigenous counterparts. They are nearly four percent of Australia's population, but they fare worse than their compatriots in life expectancy, education, housing, health and imprisonment.
